SAMPLE.center_name: OSD_Western Observatory Channel, Plymouth Marine Laboratory
SAMPLE.TITLE: OSD1_2014-06-21_0m_NPL022
SAMPLE.DESCRIPTION: To collect surface seawater on the summer solstice day from the L4 mooring in the Western English Channel (OSD1) and to filter the water using the standardized protocol NPL022. The filters will be sent to Germany and subsequently processed and analysed for the prokariotic fraction. The results will be part of the global campaign OSD data-set which will allow the scientific community to better understand the microbial diversity and function in the light of climate change assessment. The data-set so established will be used as a reference for future studies and the base for developing biotechnologies.

SAMPLE_ATTRIBUTE.VALUE: Balestreri, Cecilia, Western Observatory Channel, Plymouth Marine Laboratory; Schroeder, Declan , Western Observatory Channel, Plymouth Marine Laboratory

SAMPLE.center_name: OSD_Scripps Institute of Oceanography
SAMPLE.TITLE: OSD43_2014-06-21_0m_NE08
SAMPLE.DESCRIPTION: The Scripps pier site is a major long term coastal sampling site on the west coast of the USA. It is managed by Scripps Institution of Oceanography, UCSD and is part of the NSF-funded California Current LTER. Oceanographic parameters and the abundance of different phytoplankton taxa, from harmful algae to cyanobacteria, are regularly monitored. The ocean sampling day samples were obtained as a collaboration of SIO, NOAA, and JCVI, and with accompanying metadata will help further our understanding of ecosystem dynamics at this site by providing a snap shot of diversity at the molecular level.The Scripps pier site has been a major long term coastal sampling site on the west coast of the USA since the 1920s.

SAMPLE.center_name: OSD_University of Urbino, Dep. of Biomolecular Sciences, Section of Environmental Biology
SAMPLE.TITLE: OSD76_2014-06-20_0.5m_NE08
SAMPLE.DESCRIPTION: The assessment of the economic effects of the implementation of an active management and integrating forecasting model takes place in a Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA)approach applied to the environment. The purpose of CBA is to compare the benefits associated to a project with the costs of implementing it. CBA represents at the same time a framework for social accounting where any benefit that can be measured and monetized is weighted against all other benefits and costs. In order to develop CBA of the project, the following steps have to be considered: 1. Identifying environmental impacts of each components of the project: this activity requires the cooperation of experts of various disciplines and ends with the preparation of check-list of different impacts; 2. Quantifying impacts: data have to be gathered, and environmental impacts have to be measured. 3. Evaluating environmental impacts: these impacts can be subdivided in into market and non-market effects. Market effects are taken to be impacts that give rise to goods and/or services that for which values can be obtained by the observation of market prices. Non-market effects are taken to be impacts that give rise to goods/services for which no market prices are observable: valuation techniques are selected for placing a monetary value on these. 4. Creating cash flow statements: once the environmental impacts and the other cost and benefit components of the project are measured in monetary terms, the cash flow statement are created taking account of the accrual time of each monetary cost or benefit. 5. Discounting: in BCA the analyst must consider the different value of money accruing at different points of time. This aspect is taken into account by discounting the monetary flows and calculating indicators of project viability. In a CBA framework, avoided costs due to the implementation of the policy correspond to potential benefits. In this specific project, the main economic benefits derive from the reduction of microbial contamination in coastal waters. Their estimate is essentially based on the use values (benefits that derive from the actual use of the environment) and can be directly estimated and expressed in market prices (see step 3): a. A lower level of pollution will reduce the days of the bathing ban in local sea waters, which corresponds to an increase of tourism and sea water related activities and therefore of local GDP (the changes in the physical environment are valued through the changes in the productivity); b. A lower level of contamination of the waters translates in improved general health of citizens, i.e. avoided costs of health care and hospitalization due to infection and related diseases. A recent work (Rombaldoni et al. 2009) within a team of different experts (economists, mathematicians and biologists) was relative to the economic valuation of the Marine Protected Areas, as a tool for a sustainable fisheries management, in the Adriatic Sea (that of Fossa di Pomo, in the south-east of Italy), through the individuation of the related costs and benefits. The main benefits were environmental, but also complementary benefits were considered, such as effects on tourism and other correlated activities (among which sea exploration and biodiversity conservation).

SAMPLE_ATTRIBUTE.VALUE: Penna, Antonella, University of Urbino, Dep. of Biomolecular Sciences, Section of Environmental Biology

The purpose of CBA is to compare the benefits associated to a project with the costs of implementing it. CBA represents at the same time a framework for social accounting where any benefit that can be measured and monetized is weighted against all other benefits and costs. Identifying environmental impacts of each components of the project: this activity requires the cooperation of experts of various disciplines and ends with the preparation of check-list of different impacts; 2. Quantifying impacts: data have to be gathered, and environmental impacts have to be measured. 3. Evaluating environmental impacts: these impacts can be subdivided in into market and non-market effects. Market effects are taken to be impacts that give rise to goods and/or services that for which values can be obtained by the observation of market prices. Non-market effects are taken to be impacts that give rise to goods/services for which no market prices are observable: valuation techniques are selected for placing a monetary value on these. 4. Creating cash flow statements: once the environmental impacts and the other cost and benefit components of the project are measured in monetary terms, the cash flow statement are created taking account of the accrual time of each monetary cost or benefit. 5. Discounting: in BCA the analyst must consider the different value of money accruing at different points of time. This aspect is taken into account by discounting the monetary flows and calculating indicators of project viability. In a CBA framework, avoided costs due to the implementation of the policy correspond to potential benefits. In this specific project, the main economic benefits derive from the reduction of microbial contamination in coastal waters. Their estimate is essentially based on the use values (benefits that derive from the actual use of the environment) and can be directly estimated and expressed in market prices (see step 3): a. A lower level of pollution will reduce the days of the bathing ban in local sea waters, which corresponds to an increase of tourism and sea water related activities and therefore of local GDP (the changes in the physical environment are valued through the changes in the productivity); b. A lower level of contamination of the waters translates in improved general health of citizens, i.e. avoided costs of health care and hospitalization due to infection and related diseases. A recent work (Rombaldoni et al. 2009) within a team of different experts (economists, mathematicians and biologists) was relative to the economic valuation of the Marine Protected Areas, as a tool for a sustainable fisheries management, in the Adriatic Sea (that of Fossa di Pomo, in the south-east of Italy), through the individuation of the related costs and benefits.
